name: Barbell Romanian Deadlift
description: A hip hinge movement emphasizing the eccentric stretch of the hamstrings with the barbell maintaining constant tension throughout. The knees stay slightly bent while the hips push back, creating intense hamstring and glute engagement.
instructions: Stand holding barbell at hip height with overhand grip, feet hip-width apart
Unlock knees slightly, maintaining this angle throughout the movement
Push hips back while lowering bar along thighs and shins
Descend until hamstrings reach maximum stretch without back rounding
Drive hips forward to return to standing, squeezing glutes at top

name: Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
description: A dumbbell variation of the Romanian deadlift that allows for a more natural grip and arm path. The independent weights provide freedom of movement while still delivering excellent hamstring and glute development.
instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at thighs with neutral grip, feet hip-width apart
Maintain slight knee bend throughout the movement
Push hips back, lowering dumbbells along front of legs
Lower until strong hamstring stretch is felt, back stays flat
Drive hips forward, squeeze glutes to return to standing

name: Single-Leg Romanian Deadlift
description: A unilateral hip hinge that challenges balance, stability, and single-leg strength while targeting the hamstrings and glutes. This exercise addresses muscle imbalances and develops proprioception.
instructions: Stand on one leg holding dumbbell or kettlebell in opposite hand
Hinge at hip, extending free leg behind for counterbalance
Lower weight toward floor while keeping hips square
Descend until hamstring fully stretched or torso parallel to floor
Drive hips forward to return to standing, complete all reps then switch

name: Stiff-Leg Deadlift
description: A deadlift variation performed with minimal knee bend that maximizes hamstring stretch and engagement. Unlike the RDL, this exercise typically starts from the floor and maintains straighter legs throughout.
instructions: Stand with barbell on floor, feet hip-width apart
Hinge at hips with legs nearly straight to grip bar
Keeping legs stiff but not locked, lift bar by extending hips
Stand tall, then lower bar back to floor with minimal knee bend
Allow bar to touch floor between reps if flexibility permits

name: Good Morning
description: A barbell hip hinge exercise with the bar positioned on the upper back, emphasizing hamstring and lower back strength through a bow-like movement. Builds posterior chain strength critical for squat and deadlift performance.
instructions: Position barbell on upper back as for back squat
Stand with feet hip to shoulder width apart, slight knee bend
Push hips back and hinge forward, keeping back flat
Lower until torso is parallel to floor or hamstrings fully stretched
Drive hips forward to return to standing position

name: Cable Pull-Through
description: A hip hinge movement using a cable machine that provides constant tension through the entire range of motion. This glute and hamstring exercise is beginner-friendly and teaches proper hip hinge mechanics.
instructions: Stand facing away from low cable with rope between legs
Walk forward to create tension, feet wider than shoulder width
Hinge at hips, pushing them back while allowing cable to pull through
Keep arms straight, chest up, and back flat
Drive hips forward powerfully, squeezing glutes at top

name: Lying Leg Curl
description: A machine-based isolation exercise targeting the hamstrings through knee flexion while lying face down. This classic movement provides consistent resistance and is excellent for building hamstring size and strength.
instructions: Lie face down on leg curl machine, knees just off pad edge
Position ankle pad just above heels
Grip handles, keep hips pressed into pad
Curl heels toward glutes by bending knees
Squeeze hamstrings at top, lower with control

name: Seated Leg Curl
description: A machine isolation exercise for the hamstrings performed in a seated position with hips flexed. This angle emphasizes the hamstring muscles differently than lying variations and is often more comfortable.
instructions: Sit in machine with back against pad, thighs on seat pad
Position ankle pad above heels, legs extended
Grip handles for stability
Curl heels under seat by bending knees
Squeeze hamstrings at bottom, extend legs with control

name: Standing Leg Curl
description: A unilateral hamstring isolation exercise performed standing on a specialized machine, curling one leg at a time. This variation allows focus on each leg individually and is excellent for correcting imbalances.
instructions: Stand facing the machine, one thigh against pad
Position ankle pad behind the working heel
Hold handles for balance, standing leg slightly bent
Curl heel toward glute by bending knee
Squeeze hamstring at top, lower with control, complete all reps then switch

name: Nordic Curl
description: An advanced bodyweight hamstring exercise emphasizing the eccentric phase as you lower your body forward with feet anchored. This challenging movement builds exceptional hamstring strength and reduces injury risk.
instructions: Kneel on pad with feet anchored under secure object or held by partner
Start upright with body in straight line from knees to head
Slowly lower torso forward by extending at knees
Control descent as long as possible using hamstrings
Catch yourself with hands, push back up and use hamstrings to return
formCues: Use hands to catch and assist

name: Nordic Curl Negative
description: An eccentric-focused regression of the Nordic curl where you only perform the lowering phase, building the strength necessary for full Nordic curls. This exercise develops hamstring strength through controlled negatives.
instructions: Kneel on pad with feet anchored securely
Start upright, body in straight line from knees to head
Slowly lower torso forward for 3-5 seconds, controlling with hamstrings
Fall forward once hamstrings can no longer control descent
Catch with hands, push back to start and repeat

name: Sliding Leg Curl
description: A bodyweight hamstring exercise performed lying on your back, sliding heels toward glutes on a smooth surface. This accessible movement teaches hamstring curl mechanics and builds foundational strength.
instructions: Lie on back with heels on sliders, towels, or slick floor
Bridge hips up, body straight from shoulders to heels
Keeping hips elevated, curl heels toward glutes
Slide heels as close to butt as possible
Extend legs with control, maintaining hip bridge

name: Band-Assisted Nordic Curl
description: A Nordic curl progression using a resistance band attached overhead to provide assistance during the movement. The band reduces body weight load, allowing athletes to build strength toward full Nordic curls.
instructions: Kneel on pad with feet anchored securely
Loop resistance band around chest or hold under arms, attached above
Start upright with body straight from knees to head
Lower torso forward with control, band providing assistance
Use hamstrings to curl back up with band help
formCues: Progress to lighter bands over time

name: Swiss Ball Leg Curl
description: A hamstring curl performed with heels on a stability ball, combining knee flexion with hip extension while challenging core stability. This unstable surface increases muscle activation and coordination demands.
instructions: Lie on back with heels and lower calves on stability ball
Bridge hips up, body straight from shoulders to heels
Keeping hips elevated, curl ball toward glutes
Roll ball as close to butt as possible, squeezing hamstrings
Extend legs with control, keeping hips high throughout

name: Glute-Ham Raise
description: An advanced posterior chain exercise performed on a GHD machine that combines hip extension and knee flexion in one movement. This comprehensive exercise builds exceptional hamstring and glute strength.
instructions: Position yourself on GHD with feet secured, knees on pad
Start with torso perpendicular to floor, body forming L-shape
Lower torso forward by extending at knees while keeping hips neutral
When torso is parallel to floor, curl back up using hamstrings
Finish in starting position, squeezing glutes and hamstrings
formCues: Use hamstrings to curl back up

name: Reverse Hyper
description: A posterior chain exercise performed face down on a specialized machine, swinging the legs up and back against resistance. This movement decompresses the spine while building glute and hamstring strength.
instructions: Lie face down on reverse hyper machine, hips at pad edge
Grip handles firmly, legs hanging down with straps around ankles
Swing legs up and back by contracting glutes and hamstrings
Raise legs until body is straight or slightly hyperextended
Control the swing back down, using momentum strategically

name: Barbell Hip Thrust
description: The premier glute-building exercise performed with upper back on a bench and a loaded barbell across the hips. This movement allows for heavy loading and maximum glute activation at the top of the range.
instructions: Sit on floor with upper back against bench, barbell over hips
Roll bar to hip crease, use pad for comfort
Set feet flat on floor, shoulder-width apart, knees bent
Drive hips up by squeezing glutes until body is straight
Hold peak contraction briefly, lower with control

name: Dumbbell Hip Thrust
description: A hip thrust variation using a dumbbell positioned on the hips, providing an accessible alternative to the barbell version. This exercise is easier to set up and still delivers excellent glute activation.
instructions: Sit with upper back against bench, dumbbell resting on hip crease
Hold dumbbell in place with both hands
Set feet flat on floor, shoulder-width apart
Drive hips up by squeezing glutes until body is straight
Squeeze glutes hard at top, lower with control

name: Single-Leg Hip Thrust
description: An advanced unilateral hip thrust performed with one leg to address strength imbalances and increase intensity per leg. This challenging variation maximizes glute activation on each side independently.
instructions: Set up as for standard hip thrust with upper back on bench
Lift one leg off floor, keeping knee bent or extending straight
Drive through planted foot to raise hips until body is straight
Squeeze glute hard at top of movement
Lower with control, complete all reps then switch legs

name: Banded Hip Thrust
description: A hip thrust variation with a resistance band around the knees to increase glute medius activation through abduction resistance. The band adds an extra challenge to maintain knee position while thrusting.
instructions: Place resistance band just above knees
Set up for hip thrust with upper back on bench
Keep tension on band by pushing knees outward
Drive hips up while maintaining outward knee pressure
Squeeze glutes at top, lower with control while keeping band tension

name: Foot-Elevated Hip Thrust
description: A hip thrust variation with feet elevated on a platform or step, increasing the range of motion and challenge. The elevation allows for a deeper hip stretch at the bottom and greater glute activation.
instructions: Set up with upper back on bench, feet elevated on box or step
Position weight on hip crease if using
Allow hips to drop lower than standard due to elevation
Drive hips up powerfully, squeezing glutes at top
Lower with control through full range of motion

name: Glute Bridge
description: The foundational glute exercise performed lying on the floor, driving hips up by squeezing the glutes. This accessible movement teaches proper hip extension mechanics and serves as a building block for hip thrusts.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent, feet flat on floor hip-width apart
Arms rest at sides, palms down
Drive through heels, squeezing glutes to lift hips
Raise until body forms straight line from shoulders to knees
Squeeze glutes at top, lower with control

name: Single-Leg Glute Bridge
description: A unilateral glute bridge performed with one leg to increase difficulty and address imbalances between sides. This progression from the basic bridge significantly increases glute activation per leg.
instructions: Lie on back with one knee bent, foot flat on floor
Extend other leg straight up or hold knee toward chest
Drive through planted foot to lift hips
Raise until body is straight from knee to shoulders
Squeeze glute at top, lower with control, complete all reps then switch

name: Marching Glute Bridge
description: A dynamic glute bridge variation where you alternate lifting knees in a marching motion while maintaining hip elevation. This movement combines glute strength with core stability and hip flexor mobility.
instructions: Start in glute bridge position with hips elevated
Maintain hip height while lifting one knee toward chest
Lower that foot, then lift opposite knee
Continue alternating in marching pattern
Keep hips level and elevated throughout

name: Frog Pump
description: A glute isolation variation performed with soles of feet together and knees out in a frog position. This unique setup minimizes hamstring involvement and maximizes glute squeeze throughout the movement.
instructions: Lie on back, bring soles of feet together close to glutes
Let knees fall out to sides in frog position
Arms rest at sides or hands on hips
Drive hips up by squeezing glutes hard
Lower partially (not all the way) and repeat with continuous tension

name: Cable Kickback
description: A glute isolation exercise using a low cable and ankle attachment to extend the hip against resistance. The constant cable tension creates continuous glute engagement throughout the full range of motion.
instructions: Attach ankle strap to low cable, secure around ankle
Face machine, hold frame for support, slight forward lean
Keep working leg straight or slightly bent
Kick leg back and up by extending hip and squeezing glute
Control return to start, complete all reps then switch

name: Donkey Kick
description: A bodyweight glute exercise performed on hands and knees, kicking one leg up and back. This accessible movement isolates the glutes without equipment and is excellent for activation and higher rep work.
instructions: Start on hands and knees, hands under shoulders, knees under hips
Keep core engaged, back flat throughout
Keeping knee bent at 90 degrees, lift one leg up and back
Drive heel toward ceiling, squeezing glute at top
Lower with control, complete all reps then switch legs
commonMistakes: Kicking leg out instead of up

name: Fire Hydrant
description: A bodyweight glute exercise on hands and knees that targets the gluteus medius through hip abduction. The movement mimics a dog at a fire hydrant, lifting the leg out to the side while keeping the knee bent.
instructions: Start on hands and knees, core engaged, back flat
Keeping knee bent at 90 degrees, lift leg out to side
Raise until thigh is parallel to floor or as high as possible
Squeeze outer glute at top of movement
Lower with control, complete all reps then switch

name: Clamshell
description: A side-lying glute medius exercise where knees open and close like a clamshell while feet stay together. This rehabilitation staple builds hip stability and targets the often-neglected outer glutes.
instructions: Lie on side with knees bent 90 degrees, feet together
Stack hips vertically, head resting on arm or supported
Keep feet together as you raise top knee toward ceiling
Open legs like a clamshell, squeezing outer glute
Lower with control, complete all reps then switch sides
commonMistakes: Lifting from foot instead of knee

name: Banded Lateral Walk
description: A functional glute medius exercise walking sideways against band resistance. This movement builds hip stability, improves knee tracking, and is excellent for warm-ups or glute activation.
instructions: Place resistance band above knees or around ankles
Stand in athletic position with slight knee bend
Take wide step to side, leading with one foot
Follow with other foot, maintaining band tension
Continue stepping same direction, then reverse

name: Hip Abduction Machine
description: A machine exercise targeting the gluteus medius and outer hip by pushing legs outward against resistance. The seated position isolates the abductors and allows for progressive overload with adjustable weight.
instructions: Sit in machine with back against pad, legs inside pads
Position pads against outer thighs near knees
Grip handles for stability
Push legs outward against resistance, spreading knees apart
Squeeze outer glutes at widest point, control return

name: Cable Hip Abduction
description: A standing cable exercise where the leg is moved outward against resistance, targeting the gluteus medius. The standing position engages stabilizers and allows for functional hip abduction training.
instructions: Attach ankle strap to low cable, secure around ankle
Stand sideways to machine, strap on outside leg
Hold frame for balance, standing leg slightly bent
Lift strapped leg out to side against resistance
Squeeze outer glute at top, control return, complete all reps then switch

name: Sumo Deadlift
description: A wide-stance deadlift variation with feet outside hands that places greater emphasis on the glutes and adductors. The more upright torso position and wide stance maximize glute engagement throughout the lift.
instructions: Stand with very wide stance, toes pointed out 30-45 degrees
Grip bar between legs at shoulder width or narrower
Squat down with upright torso, hips close to bar
Drive through legs while pulling bar straight up
Stand tall, squeeze glutes at lockout, lower with control
formCues: Lock out hips fully with glute squeeze

name: Kettlebell Swing
description: A dynamic hip hinge movement swinging a kettlebell between the legs and up to shoulder height, driven primarily by explosive hip extension. This power exercise builds glute and hamstring strength while providing cardiovascular conditioning.
instructions: Stand with feet wider than shoulder width, kettlebell on floor in front
Hinge at hips to grip kettlebell with both hands
Swing kettlebell back between legs, loading glutes and hamstrings
Explosively drive hips forward, propelling kettlebell to shoulder height
Let kettlebell swing back down, hinging at hips to absorb momentum

name: 45-Degree Back Extension
description: A posterior chain exercise performed on an angled back extension bench, targeting the glutes, hamstrings, and lower back through hip extension. The 45-degree angle allows for comfortable loading and progressive overload.
instructions: Position yourself on 45-degree back extension with hips at top of pad
Cross arms over chest or hold weight plate
Lower torso toward floor by hinging at hips
Keep back flat, descend until comfortable stretch in hamstrings
Raise back up by squeezing glutes, don't hyperextend
